# Lesson 1: The Pavach Alphabet

# Letters

# Consonants Chart

Here are the official consonants of the Pavach language.

Character Name Transliteration Sound
mān m make, merge, slam
nam n neglect, ban
ŋeŋ ŋ bring
pāb p plan, clap
bap b back, crab
tād t table, flat
dat d dead, bead
kāg k cult, black
gak g gullible, bag
ᴋāɢ ᴋ guttural "k" sound
ɢaᴋ ɢ guttural "g" sound
sāz s say, gas
zas z zebra, blaze
šāž š shape, bash
žaš ž the "zh" sound
fāv f family, laugh
vaf v video, cave
θāð θ think, bath
ðaθ ð the, father
ķāģ ķ the "kh" sound
ģaķ ģ the "gh" sound
čāj č church
jač j justice
heh h hatred, behave
ʜāw ʜ heavier "h" sound
waʜ w west, beware
rāl r regulation, brag
ʀāy ʀ rolled "r" sound
lar l life, yellow
yaʀ y yellow, bouyant
ʦāǳ ʦ Nazi, rats
ǳaʦ ǳ lads
ʨāʤ ʨ ratchet, botch
ʤaʨ ʤ Djibouti, bridge
ɫāʁ ɫ rattle, bottle
ʁaɫ ʁ drain
oƜ Ɯ the "mr" sound
oɳ ɳ the "nl" sound
ʔeʔ ʔ glottal stop

# Vowels Chart

All of the consonants end with a line going towards the right. They are supposed to connect with a vowel. Vowels attach to consonants. Here are the official vowels of the Pavach language.

Character Name Transliteration Sound
sī ī east, free
sā ā ball, cop
sū ū you, clue
si i chill, in
sa a dad, that
su u sun, run
se e egg, men
ső ő look, book
so o also, post
sĩ ĩ ride, brine
sė ė price, dice
sȧ ȧ they, play
sŏ ŏ now, ouch
sȯ ȯ oyster, boy
sə ə insignificant short vowel

# Characters

# Regular Characters

Syllables are formed by combining a consonant with a vowel. For example, the consonant and the vowel combine to form the syllable .

+ =

For another example, the consonant and the vowel combine to form the syllable (which is the name of the vowel).

+ =

The consonant and the vowel combine to make a character. A character is a consonant-vowel combination, even if the consonant or vowel is not present. If both the consonant and vowel are present, as in both of the examples above, the character is called a regular character.

# Lone Consonants

Characters consisting of only a consonant (no vowel) are called lone consonants or consonant characters. They generally do not appear at the beginning of words. They usually appear at the end of words or prior to a regular character. In natural Pavach words, two lone consonants never appear consecutively.

Consider the first two syllables of my first name, .

()
()
()

The first syllable () is composed of a regular character () and a lone consonant (k). The second syllable is also a regular character () followed by a lone consonant (n).

# Lone Vowels

Vowels appear by themselves (without a preceding consonant) usually only at the beginning of words. Two consecutive lone vowels does not occur in Pavach words. Consider the name :

The opening character consists of only a vowel. This is called a lone vowel or a vowel character.
